item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: vishal
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: vishal
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:

Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)

...or something like this:

The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.

As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: vishal
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: http:.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: vishal
item.content:encoded:
Tuxarn

Learn Linux For Free With Us

When you say "I wrote a program that crashed Windows", people just stare at you blankly and say "Hey, I got those with the system, for free".

- Linus Torvalds

Upcoming Courses

Fundamentals of Red Hat Enterprise Linux

Red Hat is one of the most prominent enterprise-oriented Linux. Securing a certification with Red Hat could actually land you a job.

Learn More

Introduction to DevOps

DevOps is somewhat similar to SysAdmin role, if not exactly the same. Youll need to have some basic knowledge of Linux command line for this course.

Learn More

Explore The World Of Linux

Learn More

Different Linux Flavours

As a free and open-source operating system,Linuxhas spawned several distributions over time, spreading its wings to encompass a large community of users. From desktop/home users to Enterprise environments, Linux has ensured that each category has something to be happy about.

Learn More

item.title: Commands
item.dc:creator: vishal
item.content:encoded:
It's Time to Start Coding

Few basic commands:

pwd(Present Working Directory) Command 
It shows you the path you are currently in, starting from the root.
Its like a map that points where exactly you are so that you do not get lost.
ls Command 
It is used to see what files are there in the directory you are in.
Without the ls command we would be working blindly.
cd Command 
This command helps to change the current working directory to some other directory.
Without cd we would be stuck at the directory pointed by pwd.
ls -l 
The -l flag allows extra or longer information to be printed on the terminal. 
We can check for permissions of a certain file using this flag.
ls -i command 
The -i flag displays the inode number for each file
ls -a Command 
The -a flag reveals all hidden files and directories
touch Command 
It is used to create a blank file. i.e. initialization of a file.
mkdir(Make Directory) Command 
We can make new directories using this command.
Syntax to make one directory:
mkdir filename
Syntax to make multiple directories:
mkdir {file1.txt,file2.txt,file3.txt...}
rm Command 
We use rm to remove/delete a file.
Syntax to remove one file:
rm filename.txt
rm -r
The -r flag stands for recursive so it will delete the entire directory if used alongside rm.
Syntax
rm -r filename.txt
cat Command 
There are various uses for this command. One in particular is being able to view the contents of
a text file.
Syntax:3
cat filename1
Viewing multiple files with one cat command:
Syntax:
cat filename1 filename2 ...
Creating a file using a cat command
Syntax:
cat>filename
cp Command 
This command is used to copy a file or directory. The sources ask us to show caution as some
file may get overridden without asking for a prompt.
Syntax
cp filename1 filename2:
Here I believe the contents of filename1 gets copied to filename2.
We can copy directories using the -R flag as follows:
Syntax:
cp -R directory1 directory2
mv(Move) Command 
The mv command moves a file from one place to another or overwrites or creates a new folder
with the same or renamed name. The file at the original place won't be there if you are moving
into a new directory,
Syntax:
mv filename.txt filenamenew.txt
Here I believe the filename.txt gets renamed to filenamenew.txt.
cp(Copy) Command 
The cp command is used to copy files from files or directories into other files or directories. It
keeps a copy of the file to be copied.
Syntax:
cp filename1.txt filename2.txt
Here the contents of filename1.txt get copied to filename2.txt
top Command 
Top is a stronger task manager of windows in my opinion. We can see all the dynamic
processes and services running in the background.
Syntax:
top
nano Command 
Nano is a terminal version of notepad in windows. Its a text editor where we can write text in
and linux will remember the written data even after you shut down.We can also write shell
scripts in this text editor.
Syntax:
nano filename
pipe Command 
The | command transfers the output of one command into another command for further
processing.
Syntax:5
command1 | command2 | command3|
head Command 
The head command prints the first 10 commands of the specified file
tail Command 
The tail command print the last 10 commands of the specified file.

Intermediate Linux Commands:

chmod(Change Mode) Command 
The chmod command sets the permissions of files or directories
Syntax:
chmod u=rwx,g=rx,o=r filename
or
chmod 754 filename
Here in this command there are three types of people we need to edit our permissions on:
u stands for user.
g stands for groups.
o stands for others.
We can assign permissions by playing with the Read(r) Write(w) Execute(x) letters or by
playing with the octal numbers.
grep Command 
The grep command prints lines that match one or more patterns. After finding a match it by
default copies it to standard output or any other processing you have requested from it. Using
the pipe command with it seems interesting to me.
Syntax:
grep Linux filename.txt.
Suppose filename.txt has the words Linux is not not easy then the above command will print
this line into the terminal window.
grep -i Command 
Here taking LinuX Is nOt not easy The letters are of different cases!
The i flag takes care of case-insensitive search.
grep -c Command 
Using the c flag grep will tell you how many times the word you chose has repeated in the entire
file.
grep -o Command 
This flag will print only the word that satisfies the pattern and not the whole line.
grep -Eo Command 
I use this flag when I want to type regular expressions. The below command will succeed when
there are any numbers present in the text and print those words out.
Eg: grep Eo [0-9]+ test.txt
stat Command 
It will display detailed information about a file or directory like various timestamps, permissions,
inode number etc
Syntax:
stat filename.txt
stat --format=%i filename.txt
Using this flag, it will only display the inode number of the file. Inode number is like a unique
registration number given to all files.
df(Disk File Sysytem) Command 
The df command summarizes available and used disk space.
The -i flag displays available or unavailable inodes.
Syntax:
df -i
In(Hard Link) Command 
By default the ln command is used for creating hard links that refer to a specific place in a hard
disk, have the same inode number and multiple files can point to that same place. But changing
one changes all the others.
Syntax:
ln path
ln -s(Soft Link) Command 
The ln -s command is similar to the feature of windows shortcut. Over here the inode
numbers can be different.
find Command 
The find command can be used to find the hierarchical path for files and directories.
Syntax:
find path -inum 3670645
Here the above command will show us the path of the file that has that particular inode number.
pidof Command 
We use the pidof command to find the id of the process.
Syntax:
pidof filename
sort Command 
The sort command sorts the file in a particular order, line by line.
Syntax:
sort filename.txt
The above command will sort the contents of filename in ascending order.
sort -r filename.txt
The above command will sort the contents of filename in descending order.
ps Command 
The ps command shows details regarding the active processes running in the background.
Syntax:
ps
pkill Command 
To kill a process using its name we use pkill.
Syntax:
pkill firefox
killal Command 
It does the same job as pkill.
Syntax:
killall firefox
renice Command 
The renice command helps us with modifying scheduling priorities.
Syntax:
renice +8 PID
Here the process with PID will run slower than before as it is given a lower priority of 8.
apt Command 
The apt command is used for installing,removing and managing packages in Debian based
systems.
Syntax:
apt install/update/add/remove etc Packagename

Advanced Linux Commands:

sed Command 
The sed command is an efficient stream editor which performs text transformations while only
taking one pass over the input stream. Works well with the pipe(|) command.
Syntax:
sed 's/unix/linux/' filename.txt
Here the s specifies the substitution operation. The / are delimiters.The word unix gets
replaced with linux.
sed 's/unix/linux/g' filename.txt
Here in the above code, g signifies global, meaning it will substitute linux for unix throughout the
file document.
sed -n '2,5p' filename.txt
Here in the above code, it will print lines 2 to 5 from filename.txt document.
wc(Word Count) Command 
The wc command allows you to count all the words, lines, characters,numbers, bytes and prints
the result.
Syntax:
wc path
The above command will print 3 different numbers. Number of Line, Words and Characters.
We can choose to print number of words or number of characters by using the appropriate flags
wc -w and wc -c
awk Command 
Awk is a fully fledged scripting language and is used for data processing.10
Syntax:
awk what to process? filename.txt
Example:
awk {print $1   $4} filename.txt
awk -F , {print $1   $4} filename.txt
In the above command the -F flag changes the default separator of space to a comma.
cut Command 
Its similar to windows cut and paste. It can be used to cut parts of a line, by byte position,
character and field and then write the result to a standard output. This command needs a flag to
work.
cut -b(byte) 1,2,3 filename.txt
The -b flag extracts the specific bytes separated by commas.Here, the first, second and third
byte of every word is being written to standard output.
cut -c(column) 2,5,7 filename.txt
The -c flag selects the respective characters in the command. Here the second, fifth and
seventh letters of the word are being written to standard output.
dialog 
Linux supports 9 dialog boxes:

Dialog boxes:

msgbox 
dialog -title Welcome --msgbox My First Box 7
10
The title called Welcome will be displaced on the top of the dialog box. msgbox will create a
dialog box with a simple ok button having the data called My First Box within.7 and 10 are the
height and width of the msgbox.
backtitle 
dialog --begin 5 20 --backtitle "First Program"
--title "Welcome" --msgbox 'My first message box.'
10 30
The backtitle called First Program will be created in the top left of the screen in the background
of the dialog box. And a msgbox like the above code saying Welcome is created too.
inputbox 
dialog --stdout --inputbox "Enter your name:" 0 0 |
dialog --msgbox "Your Name is Admin" 0 0
Here the input box has a place to write text in. The rest is similar to msgbox
menu 
choice=$(dialog --stdout --menu "Choose one:" 10 30
3 1 red 2 green 3 blue)
This is a menu box where the user can choose one of the following from the list and that choice
is stored in choice variable.
checklist 
choice=$(dialog --stdout --checklist "Choose
toppings:" 10 40 3
1 Cheese on 
2 "Tomato Sauce" off 
3 Olives off)
The user is presented with a list of choices and can toggle each one on or off individually using the spacebar
radiolist 
dialog --stdout --backtitle "CPU Selection" 
--radiolist "Select CPU type:" 10 40 4 
1 ARM off 
2 Intel off 
3 PowerPC on 
4 AMD off
In a radiolist the user can make only one choice.The behaviour of radiolist is similar to checklist

echo percentage | dialog --gauge "text" height width percent
progressbar

A progressbar shows how much of a particular task has been completed.

Syntax:

echo percentage | dialog –gauge “text” height

width percent
File selection Box

FILE=$(dialog –stdout

–title “Please choose a file”

–fselect $HOME/ 14 48)

dialog –msgbox “Your Chose $FILE” 0 0

Its like browsing for files in Windows but command-prompty.
calendar

cal=$(dialog –stdout –calendar “Date” 0 0 0)

It creates a calendar in the output screen.

settings":{"title":"Few basic commands:","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"230cb66","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"345dfd7","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"e6297c6","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"pwd(Present Working Directory) Command","tab_content":"
It shows you the path you are currently in, starting from the root.
It\u2019s like a map that points where exactly you are so that you do not get lost.<\/pre>","_id":"0a920f8"},{"tab_title":"ls Command","tab_content":"
It is used to see what files are there in the directory you are in.
Without the ls command we would be working blindly.<\/pre>","_id":"eded4a8"},{"tab_title":"cd Command","tab_content":"
This command helps to change the current working directory to some other directory.
Without cd we would be stuck at the directory pointed by pwd. <\/pre>","_id":"d194e6b"},{"tab_title":"ls -l","tab_content":"
The -l flag allows extra or longer information to be printed on the terminal. 
We can check for permissions of a certain file using this flag. <\/pre>","_id":"6e67f10"},{"_id":"e78c23b","tab_title":"ls -i  command","tab_content":"
The -i flag displays the inode number for each file<\/pre>"},{"_id":"8633bbb","tab_title":"ls -a Command","tab_content":"
The -a flag reveals all hidden files and directories<\/pre>"},{"_id":"2ce921f","tab_title":"touch Command","tab_content":"
It is used to create a blank file. i.e. initialization of a file. <\/pre>"},{"_id":"94cfbe3","tab_title":"mkdir(Make Directory) Command","tab_content":"
We can make new directories using this command.
Syntax to make one directory:
mkdir \u201cfilename\u201d
Syntax to make multiple directories:
mkdir {\u201cfile1.txt\u201d,\u201dfile2.txt\u201d,\u201dfile3.txt\u201d...}<\/pre>"},{"_id":"d4966d3","tab_title":"rm Command","tab_content":"
We use rm to remove\/delete a file.
Syntax to remove one file:
rm \u201cfilename.txt\u201d
rm -r
The -r flag stands for recursive so it will delete the entire directory if used alongside rm.
Syntax
rm -r \u201cfilename.txt\u201d<\/pre>"},{"_id":"01453b1","tab_title":"cat Command","tab_content":"
There are various uses for this command. One in particular is being able to view the contents of
a text file.
Syntax:3
cat \u201cfilename1\u201d
Viewing multiple files with one cat command:
Syntax:
cat \u201cfilename1\u201d \u201cfilename2\u201d \u201c...\u201d
Creating a file using a cat command
Syntax:
cat>\u201dfilename\u201d<\/pre>"},{"_id":"c0908a1","tab_title":"cp Command","tab_content":"
This command is used to copy a file or directory. The sources ask us to show caution as some
file may get overridden without asking for a prompt.
Syntax
cp \u201cfilename1\u201d filename2\u201d:
Here I believe the contents of filename1 gets copied to filename2.
We can copy directories using the -R flag as follows:
Syntax:
cp -R \u201cdirectory1\u201d \u201cdirectory2<\/pre>"},{"_id":"efdcd40","tab_title":"mv(Move) Command","tab_content":"
The mv command moves a file from one place to another or overwrites or creates a new folder
with the same or renamed name. The file at the original place won't be there if you are moving
into a new directory,
Syntax:
mv \u201cfilename.txt\u201d \u201cfilenamenew.txt\u201d
Here I believe the filename.txt gets renamed to filenamenew.txt.<\/pre>"},{"_id":"69aa46b","tab_title":"cp(Copy) Command","tab_content":"
The cp command is used to copy files from files or directories into other files or directories. It
keeps a copy of the file to be copied.
Syntax:
cp \u201cfilename1.txt\u201d \u201cfilename2.txt\u201d
Here the contents of filename1.txt get copied to filename2.txt<\/pre>"},{"_id":"0d811fe","tab_title":"top Command","tab_content":"
Top is a stronger task manager of windows in my opinion. We can see all the dynamic
processes and services running in the background.
Syntax:
top <\/pre>"},{"_id":"f7029d1","tab_title":"nano Command","tab_content":"
Nano is a terminal version of notepad in windows. It\u2019s a text editor where we can write text in
and linux will remember the written data even after you shut down.We can also write shell
scripts in this text editor.
Syntax:
nano \u201cfilename\u201d<\/pre>"},{"_id":"f8c0587","tab_title":"pipe Command","tab_content":"
The | command transfers the output of one command into another command for further
processing.
Syntax:5
command1 | command2 | command3| \u2026 <\/pre>"},{"_id":"41d0fc3","tab_title":"head Command","tab_content":"
The head command prints the first 10 commands of the specified file<\/pre>"},{"_id":"2c7dfa2","tab_title":"tail Command","tab_content":"
The tail command print the last 10 commands of the specified file.<\/pre>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"accordion"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"03efc5f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"0124d76","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"7b1aa8f","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"http:\/\/127.0.0.1:81\/wordpress\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/1_0k_-eyWyc_fQztDqck39lQ.png","id":777},"image_size":"medium","width":{"unit":"%","size":32,"sizes":[]},"space":{"unit":"%","size":31,"sizes":[]},"opacity_hover":{"unit":"px","size":100,"sizes":[]},"image_border_radius":{"unit":"px","top":"65","right":"65","bottom":"65","left":"65","isLinked":true},"image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes","image_box_shadow_box_shadow":{"horizontal":-8,"vertical":11,"blur":10,"spread":0,"color":"rgba(0,0,0,0.5)"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"ea5570c","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"40502dd","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"72a0e7b","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Intermediate Linux Commands:","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2a5bc70","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"4eb69ae","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"222cf28","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"_id":"38e6c60","tab_title":"chmod(Change Mode) Command","tab_content":"
The chmod command sets the permissions of files or directories
Syntax:
chmod u=rwx,g=rx,o=r filename
or
chmod 754 filename
Here in this command there are three types of people we need to edit our permissions on:
u stands for user.
g stands for groups.
o stands for others.
We can assign permissions by playing with the Read(r) Write(w) Execute(x) letters or by
playing with the octal numbers. <\/pre>"},{"tab_title":"grep Command","tab_content":"
The grep command prints lines that match one or more patterns. After finding a match it by
default copies it to standard output or any other processing you have requested from it. Using
the pipe command with it seems interesting to me.
Syntax:
grep Linux filename.txt.
Suppose filename.txt has the words \u201cLinux is not not easy\u201d then the above command will print
this line into the terminal window.<\/pre>","_id":"57a4be7"},{"tab_title":"grep -i Command","tab_content":"
Here taking \u201cLinuX Is nOt not easy\u201d The letters are of different cases!
The i flag takes care of case-insensitive search.<\/pre>","_id":"6bad163"},{"_id":"48380b6","tab_title":"grep -c Command","tab_content":"
Using the c flag grep will tell you how many times the word you chose has repeated in the entire
file. <\/pre>"},{"_id":"013d72d","tab_title":"grep -o Command","tab_content":"
This flag will print only the word that satisfies the pattern and not the whole line. <\/pre>"},{"_id":"50a41e3","tab_title":"grep -Eo Command","tab_content":"
I use this flag when I want to type regular expressions. The below command will succeed when
there are any numbers present in the text and print those words out.
Eg: grep Eo \u2018[0-9]+\u2019 test.txt<\/pre>"},{"_id":"958a15c","tab_title":"stat Command","tab_content":"
It will display detailed information about a file or directory like various timestamps, permissions,
inode number etc
Syntax:
stat \u201cfilename.txt\u201d
stat --format=%i \u201cfilename.txt\u201d
Using this flag, it will only display the inode number of the file. Inode number is like a unique
registration number given to all files. <\/pre>"},{"_id":"1d5a5d2","tab_title":"df(Disk File Sysytem) Command","tab_content":"
The df command summarizes available and used disk space.
The -i flag displays available or unavailable inodes.
Syntax:
df -i<\/pre>"},{"_id":"880e4cf","tab_title":"In(Hard Link) Command","tab_content":"
By default the ln command is used for creating hard links that refer to a specific place in a hard
disk, have the same inode number and multiple files can point to that same place. But changing
one changes all the others.
Syntax:
ln \u201cpath\u201d <\/pre>"},{"_id":"b19d91d","tab_title":"ln -s(Soft Link) Command","tab_content":"
The ln -s command is similar to the feature of windows\u2019 shortcut. Over here the inode
numbers can be different. <\/pre>"},{"_id":"55322e5","tab_title":"find Command","tab_content":"
The find command can be used to find the hierarchical path for files and directories.
Syntax:
find \u201cpath\u201d -inum 3670645
Here the above command will show us the path of the file that has that particular inode number.<\/pre>"},{"_id":"371ee8c","tab_title":"pidof Command","tab_content":"
We use the pidof command to find the id of the process.
Syntax:
pidof \u201cfilename\u201d <\/pre>"},{"_id":"e525711","tab_title":"sort Command","tab_content":"
The sort command sorts the file in a particular order, line by line.
Syntax:
sort filename.txt
The above command will sort the contents of filename in ascending order.
sort -r filename.txt<\/b>
The above command will sort the contents of filename in descending order.<\/pre>"},{"_id":"cabbee4","tab_title":"ps Command","tab_content":"
The ps command shows details regarding the active processes running in the background.
Syntax:
ps <\/pre>"},{"_id":"8ca81a6","tab_title":"pkill Command","tab_content":"
To kill a process using its name we use pkill.
Syntax:
pkill firefox<\/pre>"},{"_id":"1c2f5ba","tab_title":"killal Command","tab_content":"
It does the same job as pkill.
Syntax:
killall firefox<\/pre>"},{"_id":"67ec847","tab_title":"renice Command","tab_content":"
The renice command helps us with modifying scheduling priorities.
Syntax:
renice +8 \u2018PID\u201d
Here the process with PID will run slower than before as it is given a lower priority of 8. <\/pre>"},{"_id":"c1910c9","tab_title":"apt Command","tab_content":"
The apt command is used for installing,removing and managing packages in Debian based
systems.
Syntax:
apt \u201cinstall\/update\/add\/remove etc\u201d \u201cPackagename\u201d<\/pre>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"accordion"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"0bd5243","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"518bd35","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"374916d","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"http:\/\/127.0.0.1:81\/wordpress\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/03\/download-2.png","id":785},"image_box_shadow_box_shadow_type":"yes","image_box_shadow_box_shadow":{"horizontal":0,"vertical":0,"blur":10,"spread":0,"color":"rgba(206.24999999999997, 176.20923913043478, 176.20923913043478, 0)"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"52794a8","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"7123f45","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"0c57305","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Advanced Linux Commands:","header_size":"h3"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2d6074f","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"48f6bf1","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"107538e","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"sed Command","tab_content":"
The sed command is an efficient stream editor which performs text transformations while only
taking one pass over the input stream. Works well with the pipe(|) command.
Syntax:
sed 's\/unix\/linux\/' filename.txt
Here the \u201cs\u201d specifies the substitution operation. The \u201c\/\u201d are delimiters.The word unix gets
replaced with linux.
sed 's\/unix\/linux\/g' filename.txt
Here in the above code, g signifies global, meaning it will substitute linux for unix throughout the
file document.
sed -n '2,5p' filename.txt
Here in the above code, it will print lines 2 to 5 from filename.txt document. <\/pre>","_id":"b58dddd"},{"tab_title":"wc(Word Count) Command","tab_content":"
The wc command allows you to count all the words, lines, characters,numbers, bytes and prints
the result.
Syntax:
wc \u201cpath\u201d
The above command will print 3 different numbers. Number of Line, Words and Characters.
We can choose to print number of words or number of characters by using the appropriate flags
wc -w and wc -c <\/pre>","_id":"4a74c3d"},{"_id":"ddda3c9","tab_title":"awk Command","tab_content":"
Awk is a fully fledged scripting language and is used for data processing.10
Syntax:
awk \u201cwhat to process?\u201d \u201cfilename.txt\u201d
Example:
awk \u2018{print $1 \u201c \u201c $4}\u2019 filename.txt
awk -F \u2018,\u2019 \u2018{print $1 \u201c \u201c $4}\u2019 filename.txt
In the above command the -F flag changes the default separator of space to a comma.<\/pre>"},{"_id":"faa8507","tab_title":"cut Command","tab_content":"
It\u2019s similar to windows cut and paste. It can be used to cut parts of a line, by byte position,
character and field and then write the result to a standard output. This command needs a flag to
work.
cut -b(byte) 1,2,3 filename.txt
The -b flag extracts the specific bytes separated by commas.Here, the first, second and third
byte of every word is being written to standard output.
cut -c(column) 2,5,7 filename.txt
The -c flag selects the respective characters in the command. Here the second, fifth and
seventh letters of the word are being written to standard output.<\/pre>"},{"_id":"b5c599d","tab_title":"dialog","tab_content":"
Linux supports 9 dialog boxes:<\/pre>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"accordion"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"78c52de","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"6a03ad3","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6e6e18f","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"
Dialog boxes:<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"395a87a","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"464a035","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"d0e7315","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"msgbox","tab_content":"
dialog -title \u2018Welcome\u2019 --msgbox \u2018My First Box\u2019 7\n10\nThe title called Welcome will be displaced on the top of the dialog box. msgbox will create a\ndialog box with a simple ok button having the data called \u2018My First Box\u2019 within.7 and 10 are the\nheight and width of the msgbox.<\/pre>","_id":"f08b00c"},{"tab_title":"backtitle","tab_content":"
dialog --begin 5 20 --backtitle \"First Program\"
--title \"Welcome\" --msgbox 'My first message box.'
10 30
The backtitle called \u2018First Program\u2019 will be created in the top left of the screen in the background
of the dialog box. And a msgbox like the above code saying Welcome is created too. <\/pre>","_id":"18b9147"},{"tab_title":"inputbox","tab_content":"
dialog --stdout --inputbox \"Enter your name:\" 0 0 |
dialog --msgbox \"Your Name is Admin\" 0 0
Here the input box has a place to write text in. The rest is similar to msgbox<\/pre>","_id":"850926d"},{"_id":"f354534","tab_title":"menu","tab_content":"
choice=$(dialog --stdout --menu \"Choose one:\" 10 30
3 1 red 2 green 3 blue)
This is a menu box where the user can choose one of the following from the list and that choice
is stored in choice variable.<\/pre>"},{"_id":"e9febf0","tab_title":"checklist","tab_content":"
choice=$(dialog --stdout --checklist \"Choose
toppings:\" 10 40 3
1 Cheese on \\
2 \"Tomato Sauce\" off \\
3 Olives off)
The user is presented with a list of choices and can toggle each one on or off individually using the spacebar<\/pre>"},{"_id":"db92654","tab_title":"radiolist","tab_content":"
dialog --stdout --backtitle \"CPU Selection\" \\
--radiolist \"Select CPU type:\" 10 40 4 \\
1 ARM off \\
2 Intel off \\
3 PowerPC on \\
4 AMD off
In a radiolist the user can make only one choice.The behaviour of radiolist is similar to checklist

echo percentage | dialog --gauge \"text\" height width percent<\/span><\/pre>"},{"_id":"aa31b89","tab_title":"progressbar","tab_content":"
A progressbar shows how much of a particular task has been completed.<\/span><\/p>
Syntax:<\/span><\/p>
\u00a0<\/p>
echo percentage | dialog --gauge \"text\" height\u00a0<\/span><\/p>
width percent<\/span><\/pre>"},{"_id":"6554a22","tab_title":"File selection Box","tab_content":"
FILE=$(dialog --stdout \\<\/span><\/p>
--title \"Please choose a file\" \\<\/span><\/p>
--fselect $HOME\/ 14 48)<\/span><\/p>
dialog --msgbox \"Your Chose $FILE\" 0 0<\/span><\/p>
It\u2019s like browsing for files in Windows but command-prompty.<\/span><\/pre>"},{"_id":"a3f5b14","tab_title":"calendar","tab_content":"
cal=$(dialog --stdout --calendar \"Date\" 0 0 0)<\/span><\/p>
It creates a calendar in the output screen.<\/span><\/pre>"}]},"elements":[],"widgetType":"lae-tab-slider"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]
